speaker: Dan
text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English– the show that brings you an interesting topic, authentic listening practice and six new items of vocabulary. I'm Dan…

speaker: Neil
text: And I'm Neil. We’ll be discussing the rise of those little graphics we call emojis and emoticons.

speaker: Dan
text: You know, I think emojis are a vital tool for communication. And actually, they’re not that new, either.

speaker: Neil
text: Oh really?

speaker: Dan
text: Well, that’s the perfect opportunity to ask this week’s question. When was the first emoticon used? Was it?

speaker: Neil
text: It must be 1982. I’ll go with c).

speaker: Dan
text: We’ll find out if you’re right or wrong later in the programme.

speaker: Neil
text: You know, I think we should clear one thing up before we go any further: what’s the difference between an emoticon and an emoji?

speaker: Dan
text: Good point. Emoticons came first. They’re the images made using normal keys on a keyboard – usually punctuation, letters and numbers. For example a colon – two dots - followed by the curved line of a close brackets is a…

speaker: Neil
text: A smiley face. Something you use in way too many of your emails!

speaker: Dan
text: Well, thanks! Whereas an emoji is something completely different. It’s an actual image. It could be a simple, yellow, smiley face; or something like a dancing lady; or even a bowl of noodles…

speaker: Neil
text: Ah yes, all those little images we have in our phones. But you’ll have to convince me – why do people use them so much?

speaker: Dan
text: Well, let’s listen to Professor Vyv Evans. He wrote a book called The Emoji Code:

speaker: empathyinteraction
text: They enable us to express emotion and empathy in digital communication. Increasingly, what we’re finding is that digital communication is taking over from certain aspects of face-to-face interaction. In the UK today, for example, adults spend 22 hours online on average each week. One of the reasons emojis are so interesting is that they really do enable us to express our emotional selves much more effectively.

speaker: empathy
text: Ok so he used a very useful word - empathy. It means ‘the ability to show you understand someone else’s feelings’. Ok – tell me more Dan.

speaker: empathyinteraction
text: Yes – adding an emoticon can show you understand and express emotion, and show empathy – more clearly. In digital communication we lack the visual signals we have in face-to-face interaction – as he says.

speaker: Interactioninteract
text: Interaction, meaning ‘when people or things communicate with each other’. We can also interact with things like machines, computers and social media.

speaker: non-verbalcues
text: Yes, Professor Evans says 60% of information when we’re talking to each other comes from non-verbal cues.

speaker: cue
text: Wow, that’s a lot. A cue is a signal that you need to do something.

speaker: cue
text: For example, an actor goes on stage after their cue.

speaker: non-verbalnon-verbalnon-verbal cues
text: And non-verbal means ‘without using spoken language’. So, here in the studio there are lots of other non-verbal signals about how we’re feeling - non-verbal cues. For example my facial expression, my body language, the look in my eyes, Dan.

speaker: Dan
text: There’s a glint of rage in there somewhere, Neil. Ok, so let’s apply this to digital communication. Imagine I sent you a text saying I hit my finger with a hammer – how would you respond?

speaker: Neil
text: Well, it depends. Did you hurt yourself badly?

speaker: Dan
text: If I followed it with a sad face emoji, then…?

speaker: Neil
text: Then I guess I’d know you hurt yourself. Poor you.

speaker: Dan
text: But if I followed it with a laughing emoji – the one with the tears coming out because I’m laughing so much?

speaker: clumsy
text: Then I’d probably reply saying how stupid and clumsy you are!

speaker: non-verbal cue
text: Exactly – without adding the emoji – it’s hard to know my emotional state. The emoji is the non-verbal cue – like my facial expression.

speaker: clumsyClumsyclumsy
text: By the way, is there an emoji meaning clumsy? Clumsy, means ‘physically awkward’ – someone who’s clumsy falls over a lot and drops things.Anyway, you were saying emoticons aren’t as new as I think?

speaker: Dan
text: Yes, I asked when they were invented. Is it a)1606, b)1862 or c)1982?

speaker: Neil
text: I said 1982.

speaker: Dan
text: Well, in fact, a witty speech Abraham Lincoln reprinted in a newspaper as far back as 1862 included a semi colon with a close brackets.

speaker: Neil
text: Like a winking face?

speaker: typo
text: Exactly. Though people think this was sadly just a typographical error – or what we normally call a typo.

speaker: typo
text: A typo – a spelling mistake made when typing too fast or carelessly.

speaker: Dan
text: The official birth of emoticons is usually given as 1982, when a US professor instructed his students to use smiley faces to indicate jokes - in a digital communication.

speaker: Neil
text: Wow, so they’re over 30 years old. Maybe I should start using them. Let’s round up with another look at today’s words.

speaker: empathyempathy
text: Sure. The first word we had was empathy. Do you have a lot of empathy, Neil?

speaker: empathise
text: Yes, I think I’m quite good at understanding other people’s feelings. My friends tell me that, anyway! It’s important to empathise with your colleagues too.

speaker: empathyinteraction
text: That’s not what I saw in your eyes! Yes, empathy is an important part of all human interaction.

speaker: interact
text: Nicely done. If two people interact, it means they ‘communicate with each other and react to each other’. It’s a pretty broad term.

speaker: interact
text: We could also talk about how the way children interact with the internet.

speaker: non-verbalnon-verbal
text: Way too much! Next up, we had non-verbal, meaning ‘without spoken language’. When I first travelled to Poland, I used a lot of non-verbal communication to get my message across. Hand movements, counting with fingers, things like that. Next word, Dan?

speaker: cue cuecuecue
text: Next word… that is my cue to say the next word – which is in fact – cue. A cue is a signal to do something. A commander could give his officer a cue to attack. Or I could give you a cue to… sing a song?

speaker: clumsyclumsy
text: No thanks. I’ll stick with defining words, thank you. Like clumsy – meaning ‘physically awkward’. I’d have to say Dan, you’re a sporty guy, a talented footballer - you’re not clumsy at all.

speaker: clumsy
text: That’s what I thought until I broke my leg – after a clumsy opponent ran into me…

speaker: typotypo
text: Ouch. Finally – we had type. No hang on, that’s not right. It should say typo. A typo is a mistake in a written document, or a digital file or message.

speaker: typos
text: Always check your scripts for typos before reading them, Neil. And, that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Please join us again soon!

speaker: Neil
text: And we are on social media too - Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube. See you there.

speaker: Both
text: Bye!
